TEXT: The applicant [ Mr PERSON ] is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . Before the ORG he was represented by PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
Having collected the signatures of CARDINAL mayors , as required by LAW of DATE , the applicant decided to stand as a candidate in the DATE presidential election .

By a decision of DATE ORG accepted his candidacy and by virtue of his status as a candidate the ORG paid him an advance of MONEY ( ORG ) on the lump - sum reimbursement of his campaign expenses , for which there was a ceiling of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL in force for each candidate and FRF CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL for each candidate in the second round of voting .

In the first round of the presidential election , which took place on DATE , the applicant received CARDINAL votes , or PERCENT of the votes cast . He did not take part in the second round of the election on DATE .

In accordance with Article L. CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW , which requires campaign accounts to be lodged within DATE of the second round of voting , the applicant lodged his accounts with ORG on DATE . In response to requests for further particulars on DATE and DATE from the scrutineers auditing his accounts , the applicant supplied the information and documents sought on CARDINAL DATE and DATE .

The applicant ’s accounts showed electoral expenses of ORG CARDINAL and receipts of ORG CARDINAL . The receipts were broken down as follows : an advance from the State of FRF CARDINAL , FRF CARDINAL in bank loans , FRF CARDINAL in the form of an advance from a party named “ Fédération pour une nouvelle solidarité ” ( Federation for a New Solidarity ) and ORG CARDINAL in loans made by natural persons , which included ORG CARDINAL interest - free , and ORG CARDINAL in donations .

It appears from the documents supplied by the applicant that he had personally taken out a bank loan of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL and that it had been stipulated that this loan was to be “ paid off by reimbursement of the campaign expenses ” .

The loans amounting to a total of FRF CARDINAL were made by CARDINAL individuals during the period from DATE . All but CARDINAL of these loans were interest - free and were to be repaid in full after Mr Cheminade had received the statutory lump - sum reimbursement to candidates in presidential elections . The loan contracts were sent in by the applicant after his campaign accounts had been lodged in response to the ORG requests .

The receipts of the other candidates in the presidential election amounted , for the candidates in the first round of voting only , to approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL for PERSON , ORG CARDINAL for PERSON , ORG CARDINAL for PERSON , ORG CARDINAL for Mr ORG , FRF QUANTITY for PERSON and ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL for Mr PERSON . For the CARDINAL candidates in the second round the receipts recorded in the campaign accounts were approximately ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL for PERSON and ORG CARDINAL for Mr PERSON .

LAW DATE on election by universal suffrage to the office of President of the Republic , as amended by LAW of DATE on the financing of political life , provides for a sum of PERCENT of the maximum expenses ( that is a maximum of ORG CARDINAL ) to be reimbursed in a lump - sum to each candidate who does not obtain PERCENT of the total votes cast in the first round .

This lump - sum reimbursement may not , however , exceed the amount of the candidate ’s expenses as recorded in his campaign accounts , and no reimbursement is made to candidates whose campaign accounts have been rejected .

In the present case , by a decision of DATE , ORG , which was empowered for the first time , pursuant to LAW of DATE , to approve , reject or correct the campaign accounts of candidates in a presidential election , rejected the applicant ’s campaign accounts on the following grounds :

“ It appears from the campaign accounts lodged by the candidate that he received a total of ORG stated to be interest - free loans from natural persons . The investigation has revealed that FRF CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL out of this sum , or CARDINAL of all the receipts declared , came from CARDINAL loans made after DATE . In view of the relative weight of these resources in the campaign finances as a whole , the fact that no interest was stipulated gave the candidate in the present case an advantage which must be equated with a donation pursuant to LAW Regard being had to the dates of the contracts concerned , and the scale and systematic nature of the advantages thus provided , the campaign accounts must be considered to have been drawn up in breach of PERSON DATE , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON of LAW and must accordingly be rejected . ”

The applicant was therefore deprived of the possibility of obtaining a lump - sum reimbursement of his electoral expenses to the value of ORG CARDINAL and on DATE the Minister of the ORG served him with an order to repay the FRF CARDINAL paid to him by the ORG as an advance on this reimbursement .

On DATE the ORG sent the applicant a notice to pay , which led to nothing . On DATE a bailiff drew up a report on a seizure of goods carried out with a view to the sale of furniture from the applicant ’s home , namely a period wardrobe , a desk , a bench , an armchair , a folding screen and CARDINAL books .

On DATE the applicant applied to the judge at the GPE tribunal de grande instance responsible for the execution of judgments arguing that some of the goods seized were in fact exempt from seizure and that he was entitled to a stay of execution until such time as ORG ( “ the Commission ” ) had reached a decision on the violations of the LAW alleged in the present application .
On DATE the ORG had attached CARDINAL sums of money available in the applicant ’s bank accounts .
“ Electoral transactions shall be organised according to the rules laid down by Articles ... PERSON to PERSON , PERSON and PERSON of LAW ... , subject to the following provisions .

The ceiling for electoral expenses laid down by Article L. CARDINAL - CARDINAL shall be FRF CARDINAL for a candidate for election to the office of President of the Republic . That figure shall be raised to FRF CARDINAL for each of the candidates in the second round of voting .
Campaign accounts and their annexes shall be lodged with ORG within DATE of the round of voting from which the successful candidate emerges ...
The amount of the advance payment ... must be included in the receipts recorded in the campaign accounts .

When the list of the candidates in the first round is published the ORG shall pay to each of them the sum of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL as an advance on the lump - sum reimbursement of their campaign expenses provided for in the following paragraph . Where the amount of the reimbursement does not reach that sum , the surplus must be repaid .

A sum of up to CARDINAL of the amount of the relevant ceiling for campaign expenses shall be reimbursed , in a lump - sum , to each candidate . This sum shall be increased to CARDINAL of that ceiling for each candidate who receives PERCENT of the total votes cast in the first - round ballot . It may not exceed the candidate ’s total expenses as recorded in his campaign accounts [ exceptionally , for the application of this paragraph of LAW DATE to the first election of a President of the Republic following publication of the present LAW , the proportions of CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ceiling for electoral expenses shall be raised to PERCENT and PERCENT of that ceiling respectively ] .
The lump - sum reimbursement provided for in the previous paragraph shall not be made to candidates ... whose campaign accounts have been rejected . ”

“ During DATE in which an election is held and until the date of the round of voting from which the successful candidate emerges a candidate in this election may not have collected funds with a view to financing his campaign otherwise than through an agent designated by him ... ”
“ A financial agent may collect funds only during the period contemplated in LAW . ”
“ Donations made by a duly identified natural person to finance the campaign of CARDINAL or more candidates in the same election may not exceed ORG CARDINAL . ”

“ Each candidate ... is required to keep campaign accounts recording the source of all receipts and the nature of all the expenses incurred or paid with the election in mind , other than those for the official campaign , by himself or on his behalf , during the period contemplated in LAW ... The campaign accounts must be in balance or in surplus and may not show any deficit . ”

“ Where an item of expenditure recorded in the campaign accounts costs less than the normal price , [ ORG ] shall evaluate the difference and add an equivalent sum to the campaign expenses , after inviting the candidate to produce any documentary evidence which might help to assess the circumstances . The sum thus added shall be considered a donation , within the meaning of Article PERSON , made by the natural person or persons concerned . [ The ORG ] shall deal in the same manner with all direct or indirect advantages , services and donations in kind from which the candidate has derived benefit . ”
“ CARDINAL . Taking receipts into account

( b ) The Constitutional Council further notes that in some cases funds paid in have been declared to have come from loans made by natural persons . Such loans , which may in part really constitute donations where no interest is payable , or where the rate of interest payable is lower than the usual money - market rates , make any attempt to exercise scrutiny a hit - or - miss affair . Moreover , the ORG is not in a position to verify , once the accounts have been made up , whether the contractual repayments have actually been made . Yet in the absence of such verification the payments owed by the ORG may be the cause of unjustified enrichment for the candidate . It therefore appears to be desirable for natural persons to be allowed to make only donations within the limits laid down by law , but not loans of any kind . ”
